intro: Wahlenbergia pulchella subsp. paradoxa, commonly known as the Paradoxical Bellflower, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from blue to purple. The plant typically grows in coastal or rocky habitats, thriving in well-drained soils. Its leaves are linear and often covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss in its arid environments. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family, known for its showy, tubular flowers.
